Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many people use the internet daily? Options: A. Over 1 billion, B. Over 1.5 billion, C. Over 2 billion, D. Over 2.5 billion Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the SciShow survey, what percentage of respondents prefer holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 37%, B. 45%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What occurs when the diaphragm contracts suddenly during a hiccup? Options: A. The vocal folds open, and a gulp of air exits the lungs., B. The vocal folds clamp shut, and a gulp of air enters the lungs., C. The diaphragm relaxes, and breathing becomes normal., D. The vagus nerve is stimulated, and the hiccup stops. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the role of the vagus nerve in regulating the diaphragm during hiccups? Options: A. To stimulate the diaphragm to contract more frequently, B. To distract the diaphragm from constantly contracting, C. To regulate the heartbeat only, D. To increase CO2 levels in the blood Correct Option: B
Question 5: (Removed due to duplication with question 4) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a possible way to relieve hiccups by stimulating the vagus nerve? Options: A. Holding one's breath for a long time, B. Drinking a large amount of water, C. Eating a spoonful of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can one relieve hiccups by increasing CO2 levels? Options: A. By breathing deeply and slowly, B. By holding one's breath or breathing into a paper bag, C. By drinking a large amount of water, D. By eating a spoonful of sugar Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between the diaphragm, vagus nerve, and CO2 levels in hiccup formation and relief? Options: A. The diaphragm and vagus nerve work together to regulate CO2 levels., B. The diaphragm contracts suddenly, causing the vagus nerve to stimulate and increase CO2 levels., C. The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm, which affects CO2 levels and hiccup formation., D. CO2 levels have no effect on the diaphragm and vagus nerve during hiccups. Correct Option: C
Question 9: (Removed due to duplication with question 8) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main difference between the hiccup remedies of sugar, holding one's breath, and drinking water? Options: A. Sugar stimulates the vagus nerve, while holding one's breath and drinking water increase CO2 levels., B. Holding one's breath and drinking water stimulate the vagus nerve, while sugar increases CO2 levels., C. All three remedies work by stimulating the vagus nerve., D. All three remedies work by increasing CO2 levels. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can understanding the diaphragm's role in hiccup formation and the vagus nerve's role in regulating the diaphragm lead to effective hiccup remedies? Options: A. By developing methods to stimulate the vagus nerve and regulate CO2 levels., B. By creating remedies that only target the diaphragm., C. By ignoring the role of the vagus nerve and focusing on CO2 levels., D. By developing remedies that have no scientific basis. Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is a potential area of research for new hiccup relief methods? Options: A. Exploring ways to stimulate the vagus nerve or regulate CO2 levels., B. Investigating the role of the diaphragm in hiccup formation., C. Developing remedies that target the vocal folds., D. Studying the relationship between hiccups and internet usage. Correct Option: A
Question 13: Which of the following statements is true regarding the effectiveness of hiccup remedies? Options: A. Sugar is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve., B. Holding one's breath is the most effective remedy because it increases CO2 levels., C. Drinking water is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve and increases CO2 levels., D. There is not enough evidence to determine the most effective remedy. Correct Option: D
Question 14: What is a valid critique of some hiccup remedies? Options: A. They are too expensive., B. They are not widely available., C. They lack a scientific basis and require further research., D. They are too complicated to use. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on the mechanism of hiccup formation, specifically the role of the diaphragm and vocal folds. The correct options for both questions describe the sudden contraction of the diaphragm and the subsequent clamping shut of the vocal folds, resulting in a hiccup.

Here's the generated MCQ 3 for reference:
Question 3: What occurs when the diaphragm contracts suddenly during a hiccup? 
Options: A. The vocal folds open, and a gulp of air exits the lungs., B. The vocal folds clamp shut, and a gulp of air enters the lungs., C. The diaphragm relaxes, and breathing becomes normal., D. The vagus nerve is stimulated, and the hiccup stops. 
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a diaphragm?
Options: A. A small muscle in between your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing., B. A sac of air pockets that live inside your lung and are most important for breathing., C. A nerve that runs from the base of your skull down your spine and is important for breathing., D. A sheet of muscle underneath your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many people use the internet daily? Options: A. Over 1 billion, B. Over 1.5 billion, C. Over 2 billion, D. Over 2.5 billion Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the SciShow survey, what percentage of respondents prefer holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 37%, B. 45%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What occurs when the diaphragm contracts suddenly during a hiccup? Options: A. The vocal folds open, and a gulp of air exits the lungs., B. The vocal folds clamp shut, and a gulp of air enters the lungs., C. The diaphragm relaxes, and breathing becomes normal., D. The vagus nerve is stimulated, and the hiccup stops. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the role of the vagus nerve in regulating the diaphragm during hiccups? Options: A. To stimulate the diaphragm to contract more frequently, B. To distract the diaphragm from constantly contracting, C. To regulate the heartbeat only, D. To increase CO2 levels in the blood Correct Option: B
Question 5: (Removed due to duplication with question 4) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a possible way to relieve hiccups by stimulating the vagus nerve? Options: A. Holding one's breath for a long time, B. Drinking a large amount of water, C. Eating a spoonful of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can one relieve hiccups by increasing CO2 levels? Options: A. By breathing deeply and slowly, B. By holding one's breath or breathing into a paper bag, C. By drinking a large amount of water, D. By eating a spoonful of sugar Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between the diaphragm, vagus nerve, and CO2 levels in hiccup formation and relief? Options: A. The diaphragm and vagus nerve work together to regulate CO2 levels., B. The diaphragm contracts suddenly, causing the vagus nerve to stimulate and increase CO2 levels., C. The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm, which affects CO2 levels and hiccup formation., D. CO2 levels have no effect on the diaphragm and vagus nerve during hiccups. Correct Option: C
Question 9: (Removed due to duplication with question 8) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main difference between the hiccup remedies of sugar, holding one's breath, and drinking water? Options: A. Sugar stimulates the vagus nerve, while holding one's breath and drinking water increase CO2 levels., B. Holding one's breath and drinking water stimulate the vagus nerve, while sugar increases CO2 levels., C. All three remedies work by stimulating the vagus nerve., D. All three remedies work by increasing CO2 levels. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can understanding the diaphragm's role in hiccup formation and the vagus nerve's role in regulating the diaphragm lead to effective hiccup remedies? Options: A. By developing methods to stimulate the vagus nerve and regulate CO2 levels., B. By creating remedies that only target the diaphragm., C. By ignoring the role of the vagus nerve and focusing on CO2 levels., D. By developing remedies that have no scientific basis. Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is a potential area of research for new hiccup relief methods? Options: A. Exploring ways to stimulate the vagus nerve or regulate CO2 levels., B. Investigating the role of the diaphragm in hiccup formation., C. Developing remedies that target the vocal folds., D. Studying the relationship between hiccups and internet usage. Correct Option: A
Question 13: Which of the following statements is true regarding the effectiveness of hiccup remedies? Options: A. Sugar is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve., B. Holding one's breath is the most effective remedy because it increases CO2 levels., C. Drinking water is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve and increases CO2 levels., D. There is not enough evidence to determine the most effective remedy. Correct Option: D
Question 14: What is a valid critique of some hiccup remedies? Options: A. They are too expensive., B. They are not widely available., C. They lack a scientific basis and require further research., D. They are too complicated to use. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What occurs when the diaphragm contracts suddenly during a hiccup? Options: A. The vocal folds open, and a gulp of air exits the lungs., B. The vocal folds clamp shut, and a gulp of air enters the lungs., C. The diaphragm relaxes, and breathing becomes normal., D. The vagus nerve is stimulated, and the hiccup stops. Correct Option: B

Question 8: What is the relationship between the diaphragm, vagus nerve, and CO2 levels in hiccup formation and relief? Options: A. The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm, which affects CO2 levels and hiccup formation., D. CO2 levels have no effect on the diaphragm and vagus nerve during hiccups. Correct Option: C
Question 9: (Removed due to duplication with question 8) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main difference between the hiccup remedies of sugar, holding one's breath, and drinking water? Options: A. Sugar stimulates the vagus nerve, while holding one's breath and drinking water increase CO2 levels., B. Holding one's breath and drinking water stimulate the vagus nerve, while sugar increases CO2 levels., C. All three remedies work by stimulating the vagus nerve., D. All three remedies work by increasing CO2 levels. Correct Option: A

By ignoring the role of the vagus nerve and focusing on CO2 levels., D. By developing remedies that have no scientific basis. Correct Option: A

Investigating the role of the diaphragm in hiccup formation., C. Developing remedies that target the vocal folds., D. Studying the relationship between hiccups and internet usage. Correct Option: A

Holding one's breath is the most effective remedy because it increases CO2 levels., C. Drinking water is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve and increases CO2 levels., D. There is not enough evidence to determine the most effective remedy. Correct Option: D
Question 14: What is a valid critique of some hiccup remedies? Options: A. They are too expensive., B. They are not widely available., C. They lack a scientific basis and require further research., D. They are too complicated to use. Correct Option: C

Matching Response:

**Question 11: How can understanding the diaphragm's role in hiccup formation and the vagus nerve's role in regulating the diaphragm lead to effective hiccup remedies?**

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it:

1. Focuses on the underlying mechanism of hiccup formation and relief.
2. Involves the diaphragm and the vagus nerve, which are key components in the ground truth MCQ.
3. Implies that understanding the relationship between the diaphragm and the vagus nerve can lead to effective hiccup remedies, which is similar to the ground truth MCQ's focus on "hitting the reset button" on the nervous system to stop hiccups.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?
Options: A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone., B. Swallowing sugar is too sweet. It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Swallowing sugar causes your body to inhale a large amount of oxygen which calms your diaphragm.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many people use the internet daily? Options: A. Over 1 billion, B. Over 1.5 billion, C. Over 2 billion, D. Over 2.5 billion Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the SciShow survey, what percentage of respondents prefer holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 37%, B. 45%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What occurs when the diaphragm contracts suddenly during a hiccup? Options: A. The vocal folds open, and a gulp of air exits the lungs., B. The vocal folds clamp shut, and a gulp of air enters the lungs., C. The diaphragm relaxes, and breathing becomes normal., D. The vagus nerve is stimulated, and the hiccup stops. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the role of the vagus nerve in regulating the diaphragm during hiccups? Options: A. To stimulate the diaphragm to contract more frequently, B. To distract the diaphragm from constantly contracting, C. To regulate the heartbeat only, D. To increase CO2 levels in the blood Correct Option: B

Question 7: How can one relieve hiccups by increasing CO2 levels? Options: A. By breathing deeply and slowly, B. By holding one's breath or breathing into a paper bag, C. By drinking a large amount of water, D. By eating a spoonful of sugar Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between the diaphragm, vagus nerve, and CO2 levels in hiccup formation and relief? Options: A. The diaphragm and vagus nerve work together to regulate CO2 levels., B. The diaphragm contracts suddenly, causing the vagus nerve to stimulate and increase CO2 levels., C. The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm, which affects CO2 levels and hiccup formation., D. CO2 levels have no effect on the diaphragm and vagus nerve during hiccups. Correct Option: C

All three remedies work by increasing CO2 levels. Correct Option: A

By ignoring the role of the vagus nerve and focusing on CO2 levels., D. By developing remedies that have no scientific basis. Correct Option: A

Investigating the role of the diaphragm in hiccup formation., C. Developing remedies that target the vocal folds., D. Studying the relationship between hiccups and internet usage. Correct Option: A
Question 13: Which of the following statements is true regarding the effectiveness of hiccup remedies? Options: A. Sugar is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve., B. Holding one's breath is the most effective remedy because it increases CO2 levels., C. Drinking water is the most effective remedy because it stimulates the vagus nerve and increases CO2 levels., D. There is not enough evidence to determine the most effective remedy. Correct Option: D
Question 14: What is a valid critique of some hiccup remedies? Options: A. They are too expensive., B. They are not widely available., C. They lack a scientific basis and require further research., D. They are too complicated to use. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the video, we see that one failure point is if she builds a treehouse, she may be able to stay in but can't have friends over. What is a failure point?
Options: A. A place where a solution to a problem fails., B. A place where a solution to a problem has limits., C. A place where a solution to a problem causes a collapse in the solution., D. A place where a solution to the problem causes another unknown variable.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary purpose of the engineering process? Options: A. To design buildings, B. To conduct scientific experiments, C. To solve problems, D. To create art Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the term for potential weaknesses in a design that can cause it to fail? Options: A. Variables, B. Failure points, C. Design elements, D. Prototypes Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why is it essential to define a problem and consider multiple solutions in the engineering process? Options: A. To save time and resources, B. To ensure the success of a design, C. To identify potential failure points, D. To create a unique solution Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the role of architecture in designing buildings? Options: A. To create aesthetically pleasing structures, B. To design buildings that meet specific needs, C. To conduct scientific experiments, D. To develop new materials Correct Option: B
Question 5: A student wants to design a treehouse that meets specific needs. What process should they use? Options: A. Scientific method, B. Engineering process, C. Architectural design process, D. Trial and error Correct Option: B
Question 6: A company wants to improve an existing product. What process should they use? Options: A. Marketing strategy, B. Engineering process, C. Financial analysis, D. Quality control Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between the size of a treehouse and its weight? Options: A. The larger the treehouse, the lighter it will be, B. The larger the treehouse, the heavier it will be, C. The size of the treehouse has no effect on its weight, D. The weight of the treehouse has no effect on its size Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the purpose of identifying potential failure points in a design? Options: A. To create a unique solution, B. To ensure the success of a design, C. To develop strategies to mitigate them, D. To ignore them and move forward Correct Option: C
Question 9: A student wants to design a treehouse with a drop-down rope ladder and windows. What process should they use to combine these design elements? Options: A. Trial and error, B. Engineering process, C. Architectural design process, D. Scientific method Correct Option: B
Question 10: A company wants to develop a new product that meets specific needs and criteria. What process should they use? Options: A. Marketing strategy, B. Engineering process, C. Financial analysis, D. Quality control Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the primary criterion for evaluating the effectiveness of a design? Options: A. Aesthetics, B. Cost, C. Functionality, D. Meeting specific needs and criteria Correct Option: D
Question 12: Why is it essential to justify the choice of a particular design element? Options: A. To convince others of its effectiveness, B. To ensure the success of a design, C. To identify potential failure points, D. To create a unique solution Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the term for potential weaknesses in a design that can cause it to fail. The correct option, "Failure points," is also the same concept as the correct option in the ground truth MCQ. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X approached the Civil Rights Movement differently, they did have two things in common. What were they?
Options: A. They were both ministers and they both grew up in Nebraska., B. They were both ministers and they were both assassinated., C. They were both assassinated and they both found religion as adults., D. Both had sick mothers who died and fathers that were ministers.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Malcolm X born? Options: A. New York, New York, B. Omaha, Nebraska, C. Montgomery, Alabama, D. Los Angeles, California Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was Malcolm X's birth name? Options: A. Malcolm Shabazz, B. Malcolm Little, C. Malcolm X, D. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz Correct Option: B
Question 3: What event in Malcolm X's life marked a significant turning point, leading to his transformation into a prominent leader? Options: A. His father's murder, B. His time in foster care, C. His discovery of Islam while in prison, D. His conversion to traditional Islam Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did Malcolm X's early life experiences influence his later involvement in the Civil Rights Movement? Options: A. They led him to reject the movement, B. They had no impact on his involvement, C. They influenced his decision to join the Nation of Islam, D. They motivated him to fight against racism and oppression Correct Option: D
Question 5: How can Malcolm X's life story be applied to contemporary social justice movements? Options: A. As an example of the importance of compromise, B. As a cautionary tale about the dangers of activism, C. As a powerful example of personal transformation and standing up against racism and oppression, D. As a justification for violent means to achieve social change Correct Option: C
Question 6: What can be learned from the differing approaches of Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in the context of social change? Options: A. That violence is always the most effective means, B. That nonviolent resistance is the only effective means, C. That different approaches can be applied to achieve social change, D. That only one approach can be effective in achieving social change Correct Option: C
Question 7: What does the contrast between Malcolm X's early life experiences and his later success as a leader highlight? Options: A. The impact of privilege and wealth, B. The significance of personal connections in achieving success, C. The power of resilience and determination in overcoming adversity, D. The role of luck in achieving success Correct Option: C
Question 8: What does the relationship between Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. demonstrate? Options: A. The uniformity of perspectives within the Civil Rights Movement, B. The diversity of perspectives and approaches within the Civil Rights Movement, C. The irrelevance of personal relationships in achieving social change, D. The unimportance of leadership in social movements Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can be gained by examining the lives of Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.? Options: A. A deeper understanding of the simplicity of the Civil Rights Movement, B. A deeper understanding of the complexities and nuances of the Civil Rights Movement, C. A justification for rejecting the Civil Rights Movement, D. A complete understanding of the Civil Rights Movement Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be seen as a testament to the power of personal growth and redemption in Malcolm X's life? Options: A. His early life experiences, B. His time in prison, C. His transformation from a troubled youth to a prominent leader, D. His conversion to traditional Islam Correct Option: C
Question 11: What does Malcolm X's phrase "By any means necessary" reflect? Options: A. A commitment to nonviolent resistance, B. A willingness to use violence to achieve social change, C. A sense of urgency and desperation in the face of racism and oppression, D. A rejection of the Civil Rights Movement Correct Option: C
Question 12: How effective was Malcolm X's leadership in advancing the goals of the Civil Rights Movement? Options: A. Very effective, because he achieved all of his goals, B. Not effective at all, because he was too divisive, C. Effective in bringing attention to important issues and inspiring a new generation of activists, D. Completely ineffective, because he was assassinated before achieving any significant change Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 8: What does the relationship between Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. demonstrate?**

Options: A. The uniformity of perspectives within the Civil Rights Movement, B. The diversity of perspectives and approaches within the Civil Rights Movement, C. The irrelevance of personal relationships in achieving social change, D. The unimportance of leadership in social movements

Correct Option: B

This generated MCQ is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ because it:

1. Compares Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
2. Discusses their approaches to the Civil Rights Movement
3. Highlights the diversity of perspectives and approaches within the movement

Although the question wording and options are not identical, the intent and content of Question 8 are closest to the ground truth MCQ.

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. They were being attacked by the Ku Klux Klan., B. His father received an important job elsewhere., C. His mother became ill and they moved to be closer to a hospital., D. They didn't have enough money to stay in Omaha.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the dimensions of the cursed chessboard?
Options: A. 4 by 4, B. 5 by 5, C. 6 by 6, D. 8 by 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the size of the chessboard used to trap MoldeVort? Options: A. 3x3, B. 4x4, C. 5x5, D. 6x6 Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following is a well-known Pythagorean triple? Options: A. 1, 2, 3, B. 2, 3, 4, C. 3, 4, 5, D. 4, 5, 6 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main goal in the problem regarding MoldeVort's movement on the chessboard? Options: A. To move MoldeVort to the center of the board, B. To keep MoldeVort on the blue and red spaces, C. To move MoldeVort to the corners of the board, D. To keep MoldeVort on the orange and inside spaces Correct Option: B
Question 4: How can larger movements on the board be enabled to trap MoldeVort? Options: A. By using horizontal movements, B. By using vertical movements, C. By using diagonals, D. By using a combination of horizontal and vertical movements Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is a possible real-world application of the problem-solving strategy used in this problem? Options: A. Financial analysis, B. Marketing research, C. Human resources management, D. Game development Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is a practical application of the Pythagorean Theorem? Options: A. Calculating the area of a circle, B. Calculating the volume of a sphere, C. Designing buildings and bridges, D. Analyzing statistical data Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the chosen numbers and MoldeVort's movement on the chessboard? Options: A. The chosen numbers determine the direction of MoldeVort's movement, B. The chosen numbers determine the distance of MoldeVort's movement, C. The chosen numbers have no effect on MoldeVort's movement, D. The chosen numbers can lead to MoldeVort's escape if not chosen correctly Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main difference between the blue and red spaces, and the orange and inside spaces on the chessboard? Options: A. The blue and red spaces are closer to the center of the board, B. The blue and red spaces are safer than the orange and inside spaces, C. The blue and red spaces are more difficult to reach than the orange and inside spaces, D. The blue and red spaces are more abundant than the orange and inside spaces Correct Option: B
Question 9: What key concept can be combined with the Pythagorean Theorem to develop a winning strategy? Options: A. Probability, B. Statistics, C. Geometry, D. Symmetry Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the result of integrating the understanding of MoldeVort's movement and the chosen numbers? Options: A. A list of possible numbers to choose from, B. A comprehensive plan to keep MoldeVort trapped, C. A calculation of the probability of MoldeVort's escape, D. A diagram of the chessboard with the safe spaces marked Correct Option: B
Question 11: Why are the numbers 1, 3, 4, and 5 effective in keeping MoldeVort trapped? Options: A. Because they are the smallest possible numbers, B. Because they are the largest possible numbers, C. Because they form a Pythagorean triple and use symmetry to limit MoldeVort's movement, D. Because they are randomly chosen numbers Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the importance of considering symmetry in solving the problem? Options: A. It makes the problem more complex, B. It makes the problem easier to visualize, C. It reduces the problem to three types of spaces, making it easier to solve, D. It has no effect on the solution Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the Pythagorean Theorem, and how is it used in the problem? Options: A. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is used to calculate the distance between two points on the chessboard., B. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is used to calculate the area of the chessboard., C. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is used to calculate the perimeter of the chessboard., D. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is not used in the problem. Correct Option: A
Question 14: How does the use of symmetry in the problem help to reduce the number of possible spaces to consider? Options: A. By dividing the chessboard into four quadrants, B. By dividing the chessboard into three types of spaces (blue, red, and orange), C. By dividing the chessboard into two types of spaces (safe and unsafe), D. By dividing the chessboard into individual squares Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the ultimate goal of the problem, and how is it achieved? Options: A. The ultimate goal is to trap MoldeVort, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement., B. The ultimate goal is to free MoldeVort, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement., C. The ultimate goal is to move MoldeVort to the center of the board, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement., D. The ultimate goal is to keep MoldeVort on the orange and inside spaces, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

The ground truth MCQ asks about the dimensions of the cursed chessboard, and Question 1 asks about the size of the chessboard used to trap MoldeVort. Both questions have similar intent and content, and the options provided are also similar, with the correct option being 5x5 (or 5 by 5) in both cases.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

If I had to choose an index, I would say 7 is the most similar, but please note that it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What do the numbers do?
Options: A. They specify the distance Moldevort must move., B. They specify the time Moldevort must spend in each spot., C. They specify how much money Moldevort must pay you., D. They don’t do anything.
Correct Option: A

Question 4: How can larger movements on the board be enabled to trap MoldeVort? Options: A. By using horizontal movements, B. By using vertical movements, C. By using diagonals, D. By using a combination of horizontal and vertical movements Correct Option: C

Question 6: What is a practical application of the Pythagorean Theorem? Options: A. Calculating the area of a circle, B. Calculating the volume of a sphere, C. Designing buildings and bridges, D. Analyzing statistical data Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between the chosen numbers and MoldeVort's movement on the chessboard? Options: A. The chosen numbers determine the direction of MoldeVort's movement, B. The chosen numbers determine the distance of MoldeVort's movement, C. The chosen numbers have no effect on MoldeVort's movement, D. The chosen numbers can lead to MoldeVort's escape if not chosen correctly Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the main difference between the blue and red spaces, and the orange and inside spaces on the chessboard? Options: A. The blue and red spaces are closer to the center of the board, B. The blue and red spaces are safer than the orange and inside spaces, C. The blue and red spaces are more difficult to reach than the orange and inside spaces, D. The blue and red spaces are more abundant than the orange and inside spaces Correct Option: B
Question 9: What key concept can be combined with the Pythagorean Theorem to develop a winning strategy? Options: A. Probability, B. Statistics, C. Geometry, D. Symmetry Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the result of integrating the understanding of MoldeVort's movement and the chosen numbers? Options: A. A list of possible numbers to choose from, B. A comprehensive plan to keep MoldeVort trapped, C. A calculation of the probability of MoldeVort's escape, D. A diagram of the chessboard with the safe spaces marked Correct Option: B
Question 11: Why are the numbers 1, 3, 4, and 5 effective in keeping MoldeVort trapped? Options: A. Because they are the smallest possible numbers, B. Because they are the largest possible numbers, C. Because they form a Pythagorean triple and use symmetry to limit MoldeVort's movement, D. Because they are randomly chosen numbers Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the importance of considering symmetry in solving the problem? Options: A. It makes the problem more complex, B. It makes the problem easier to visualize, C. It reduces the problem to three types of spaces, making it easier to solve, D. It has no effect on the solution Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the Pythagorean Theorem, and how is it used in the problem? Options: A. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is used to calculate the distance between two points on the chessboard., B. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is used to calculate the area of the chessboard., C. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is used to calculate the perimeter of the chessboard., D. The Pythagorean Theorem states that the sum of the squares of the sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse, and it is not used in the problem. Correct Option: A
Question 14: How does the use of symmetry in the problem help to reduce the number of possible spaces to consider? Options: A. By dividing the chessboard into four quadrants, B. By dividing the chessboard into three types of spaces (blue, red, and orange), C. By dividing the chessboard into two types of spaces (safe and unsafe), D. By dividing the chessboard into individual squares Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the ultimate goal of the problem, and how is it achieved? Options: A. The ultimate goal is to trap MoldeVort, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement., B. The ultimate goal is to free MoldeVort, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement., C. The ultimate goal is to move MoldeVort to the center of the board, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement., D. The ultimate goal is to keep MoldeVort on the orange and inside spaces, and it is achieved by choosing the correct numbers and using symmetry to limit his movement. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. If he can overpower the spell with magical strength., B. If he can’t make a legal move without going off the board or off the center of a square., C. If he finds the enchanted chess pieces., D. If he can reverse the spell using a symmetry spell.
Correct Option: B
